Award.AwardTitle: Applying High-resolution GPS Tracking to Characterize Sensory Foraging Strategies of the Black-browed Albatross, a Top Predator of the Southern Ocean Ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
With 70% of the Earth's surface being covered by oceans, a longstanding question of interest to the ecology of migratory seabirds is how they locate their prey across such vast distances. The project seeks to investigate the sensory strategies used in the foraging behavior of procellariiform seabirds, such as petrels, albatrosses and shearwaters. These birds routinely travel over thousands of kilometers of open ocean, apparently using their pronounced olfactory abilities (known to be up to a million times more sensitive than other birds) to identify productive marine areas or locate prey. High resolution tracking, such as provided by miniaturized GPS data loggers (+/- 5m; 10 second sampling), are needed to gain insight into some of the questions as to the sensory mechanisms birds use to locate their prey. Combining these tracking and positioning devices along with stomach temperature recorders capable of indicating prey ingestion, will provide a wealth of new behavioral information. Species specific foraging based on prey specific odors (e.g. krill vs fisheries vs. squid), and mixed strategies using olfaction and visual cues appear to be different for these different marine predators.

Albatrosses are increasingly an endangered species globally, and additional information as to their foraging strategies might lead to better conservation measures such as the avoidance of by-catch by long-line fisheries.
Intimate details of each species foraging activity patterns during the day and night and insight into the conservation of these top predators in pelagic Southern Ocean ecosystems are a few of the research directions these novel fine scale resolution approaches are yielding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Procellariiform seabirds such as petrels and albatrosses forage over vast expanses of open ocean in search of prey. To characterize sensory search strategies, we teamed up with Dr. Henri Weimerskirch, of CNRS, France, who has consistently been on the leading edge of developing and adapting tracking and behavioral monitoring technologies to study freely ranging seabirds. 

Our objective was to collect tracking data (GPS location and stomach temperature recordings) in order to test specific hypotheses about foraging behavior linked to the use of vision and olfaction to find prey.  We record GPS locations to be able to measure their flight direction relative to wind and we record their stomach temperature to determine when and how much prey they ingest (Figure 1). Our approach was to compare data collected from Blackbrowed albatross with similar data that had previously been collected from Wandering albatross. To record their stomach temperature, we used the same devices used previously on Wandering albatross, but we ran into some difficulties because the Blackbrowed albatross quickly regurgitated them, preventing us from being able to confirm feeding points and quantify prey consumption.  We had to modify our analysis to use a machine learning technique to identify a signature in the GPS track unique to foraging behavior. We were able to apply this method to both Blackbrowed and Wandering albatross data to make comparisons between species. This method eventually allowed us to quantify the types of flight patterns associated with foraging, but it was less successful than actual stomach temperature data in accurately predicting where foraging events occurred.  In summary, although the sample size is considerably smaller, we found that the Blackbrowed albatross tracks share many features that, in prior studies of Wandering albatross, suggested the use of olfactory search. In many instances we observed cross-wind transects to and from the breeding colony, but also observed sharp upwind turns and upwind zig-zag flight, indicative of tracking prey by scent. A notable feature that had not been previously described suggests that the birds are using odor cues to return to the island, and we are analyzing these instances in more detail prior to publishing the results.

This award also contributed to related important discoveries. With colleagues from The Vision Group at Lund University in Sweden, we published results suggesting that highly developed olfaction is linked to very poor vision in procellariiforms. We also used our extensive behavioral database of sensory-based foraging to investigate links between olfactory foraging and nutrient cycling in the Southern Ocean. In part because we had initial difficulties with our experimental subjects rejecting the plastic-coated stomach temperature pills, we also did a broader investigation of deleterious plastic ingestion by procellariiform seabirds and discovered that bio-fouled plastic gives off a scent called dimethyl sulfide (DMS) that normally leads seabirds to food.

Finally, funding from this award allowed us to explore a new technique for examining olfactory foraging in free ranging seabirds such as the albatross. The concept is to measure in-situ the presence of an olfactory cue, specifically dimethyl sulfide (DMS) that we know is used by certain species of procellariiform seabirds to forage. We have previously only been able to infer from a change in flight track that a foraging bird has responded to an olfactory cue. By taking direct measurements of DMS, we expect to confirm that the behavior occurs in the presence of the cue. NASA has developed a novel form of gas sensor based on nano-materials that differs significantly from previous technologies in ways that make it suitable to be flown on a bird such as an albatross. We have worked with NASA to modify the sensor for our use, and this award allowed us to design and build the test equipment needed to evaluate the sensor in preparation for a future deployment. Unfortunately, despite NASA's help, we were not able to acquire the actual sensor for testing at our University. Although the award has ended, we are keen to continue the project, and believe it will contribute significantly to the future of animal-borne atmospheric research.

In terms of Broader Impacts, this award helped to foster an international partnership between CNRS in France and Dr. Nevitt's home institution, University of California, Davis, through collaborative and logistical support from Dr. Henri Weimerskirch's established study sites, and his extensive team of research assistants. This research project provided funding and training opportunities to graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar, including a Hispanic male and a female student.  We also collaborated with the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration's Cordell Bank National Marine Sanctuary to host workshops entitled "Ocean Literacy through the eyes of an Albatross" to teach local teachers about ocean health for grades 6-12.
